bibl.title: Letter from Bertha L. Lyons to Philip Showalter Hench, March 12, 1948

div1.p: Lyons requests that Hench send photostats and photographs of specific items from the general list of data in his possession. The material will be used in the Hall of Fame program for the unveiling of the Walter Reed bust.

div1.head: Letter from Bertha L. Lyons to Philip Showalter Hench, March 12, 1948
div1.opener:
Every American is a shareholder in the Hall of Fame
HALL OF FAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY
I MADISON AVENUE · NEW YORK IO, N. Y.
Telephone: MURRAY HILL 3-4469
12 March 1948.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Dr. Angell has carefully gone over your list
of memorabilia, and we would like very much to have photographs
or photostats of the following:
From the list which you suggested in your letter of February 23:

Items 2, 3, 4 and 5. You have sent us a photostat copy of the
letter covered in item 5, but we would appreciate having another
photostat of this letter, with the addition of the one dated
January 1, 1901, with Reed's signature, please. The former
photostat did not have Reed's signature. Also, we should like
items 8, 9, 10, 13, 14 and 15 no

In addition to the above, we should also like photostats
and photographs of the following items shown on your general list of
data in your possession:
10 - A photograph of this little smokestack might be interesting to
reproduce with the building #1.
18 - Photostats of a few of the clippings from the scrap book -
some which you think of great interest.
? -
21 - The paper cutter.
23 - Again, some of these photographs which you think would be inter-
esting for our purpose.
Birthplace
25 - A photostat of this if you think it is not too technical for
the program.
42 - In addition to some original letters of Gorgas and General
Wood, we would like very much to have the letter of Sir William
Osler, quoted by Col. J. R. Kean in his address as given in
The Military Surgeon of March, 1928, p. 293, and which reads
as follows: “. . . of the altruistic instincts, veneration
is not the most highly developed at the present day;
but I hold strongly with the statement that it is
the sign of a dry age when the great men of the
past are held in light esteem.”
dont have
We should also like to have photostats of one or two letters
from Dr. Welch, particularly the one appraising Walter Reed's
work. Some of those letters are reproduced in Dr. Kelly's
book; others in General Truby's volume, but I regret to say
they are not always reproduced correctly. Particularly, in
the letter from Walter Reed to Mrs. Reed, of which you kindly
-2-
12 March 1948
sent a photostat (Dec. 31, 1900) we noticed inaccuracies in both
Dr. Kelly's book and General Truby's “Memoir of Walter Reed.”
Should also like items
45, 48 (one or two of each - critical and complimentary;) 49 -one
or two letters from General Kean which you think most import-
ant in their relationship; 57 and 62, all of these from your
typed list.

We hesitate to ask you aseemble this long list of material
for us (if, indeed, you will be good enough to do it for us), but we
do wish to assume the expense for all photostats and photographs.
You know, of course, that we are planning only a 16 page program,
and that we shall use about three or four pages for the Order of Exer-
cises and Hall of Fame data, which would leave us only 12 or 13 pages
for material relating to Reed. With this in mind, and the fact that
our fund does not permit of very large expenditures for photographic
material, we must rely entirely upon your judgment in dealing with
the items indicated by us.

We had a gracious letter from General Reed authorizing the
use of any material, from any source, for the program.

You may also be interested to know that Wyeth, Inc. are making
new plates, suitable for our program, and we expect proof at any
moment. Again, I wish to express our deep appreciation for your
suggestions regarding the use of the painting, as well as for all
of your other suggestions of letters, photographs, etc., etc.
div1.closer:
Cordially yours, Bertha L. Lyons
Assistant to the Director
P.S. I sincerely hope you and Mrs. Hench had a beneficial holiday.
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
PP.S. Your list covering items in your possession is returned
with appreciative thanks. We have made a copy of it for
reference purposes.
